list: Condominium (condo) - essentially an apartment that you own
Seems like a good idea because it has lots of cool surrounding things
Pro - you don’t have to maintain the exterior
Con - very high community expenses (charged by the Home Owners Association)
Townhouse - 1-3 stories, but attached to other people’s townhouses
Cheaper than condos and houses
Single Family Houses - the typical house
Multi-family Complex - for example: duplex, 4-plex, 8-plex
If you buy these and rent out the other living spaces, you will receive more in rent than your mortgage

subtopics.par: The standard these days is that your mortgage will cover all 4 components, but sometimes it will only be the first 2.
list: Principal - portion of the house that you still have to pay off
Interest - percentage paid of the remaining principal
Deductible from your federal income tax upto 10k
Tax - property tax levied by your state, city, and county as a percentage of your total property value collected yearly
Also deductible from your taxes
Insurance
When loan interest rates are lower than your original interest rate, you can refinance your mortgage with your bank at that lower rate
This will significantly lower your mortgage
It's almost like buying your house again
Generally, you are required to pay ~20% in a down payment (immediate payment; the rest is through mortgage)
The easiest way to buy a house is by contacting a realtor
Credit history matters a lot because you are taking a big loan, and can affect your interest rate
Price is based on square footage and neighborhood
Location matters
Nearby public transport is good
Being near a school is a good, but not too close that it’s a disturbance
The value of houses slowly increases over time
